review.body:
Nice work.
Just a couple of small further improvements suggested.
Plus the other changes and test extensions already planned for.

pull_request.title: apps: req/x509 add explicit start and end date
pull_request.body:
This feature adds options to explicitly set the start and end dates in X509v3 certificate creation with the `req` and `x509` apps.
I stumbled upon this several times now, and I think this adds some convenience to the apps.

For the `req` app, I borrowed the naming from the `ca` app, hence the parameters are called `-startdate` and `-enddate`. I also added the same handling for `default_startdate` and `default_enddate` to the respective configuration file section.
The `-enddate` option conflicts with the `-days` option, hence only one of both can be used. If a start date is given, but no end date, the `-days` option is processed instead. Currently, this results in an offset of days from the current date, not from the start date.

For the `x509` app, I had to select different names, as `-startdate` and `-enddate` are already in use to print the `notBefore` and `notAfter` fields of a certificate. Therefore, I called the options `-notbefore` and `-notafter`. The handling in respect to the `-days` option is similar to the `req` app, but no configuration file parameters exist.

Changes:
- removed new configuration options from `req` app.
- renamed options `-startdate` and `-enddate` to `-notbefore` and `-notafter` in `req` app.
- Ensure notafter >= notbefore in both apps `req` and `x509`.
- Improved docs.

If this fixes a GitHub issue, make sure to have a line saying 'Fixes #XXXX' (without quotes) in the commit message.
-->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -324,11 +326,27 @@ Sets the "CA" private key to sign a certificate with.
 The private key must match the public key of the certificate given with B<-CA>.
 If this option is not provided then the key must be present in the B<-CA> input.
 
+=item B<-startdate> I<date>
+
+This allows the start date to be explicitly set. The format of the
+date is YYMMDDHHMMSSZ (the same as an ASN1 UTCTime structure), or
+YYYYMMDDHHMMSSZ (the same as an ASN1 GeneralizedTime structure). In
+both formats, seconds SS and timezone Z must be present.
comment.body:
No, all uses of `set_cert_times()` support `startdate` (and thus `-not_before`) being "today".
BTW, you could easily extend this also to `enddate` (for use with `-not_after`).

issue.body:
This adds reproducible memory error and test-data
error injection, to the fuzzy-test framework.

This feature can be enabled with ./config -DERROR_INJECT and additionally to enable call stacks -DERROR_CALLSTACK

If enable-asan is used, the callstack is printed by the sanitizer, otherwise please set a breakpoint
at the function "break_here", which is executed each time a memory allocation error is injected.

If called with the environment variable ERROR_INJECT defined to the empty string the initialization value is printed, and can be used to reproduce the failure later, by passing the value to the ERROR_INJECT variable.

There is a search script that can be used to look
for errors, and print the command to reproduce the bug:

./testrun.sh

This runs in endless mode until an error is found.

pull_request.body:
Free functions are expected to be tolerant of a NULL pointer being passed.

Fixes the problem in
https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/21668#issuecomment-1782718328

issue.body:
OpenSSL's encoding of SM2 keys used the SM2 OID for the algorithm OID
where an AlgorithmIdentifier is encoded (for encoding into the structures
PrivateKeyInfo and SubjectPublicKeyInfo).

Such keys should be encoded as ECC keys.

Fixes #22184

comment.body: Seeing further discussions in #22184, and digging into what standards we have available, this PR may turn out to be quite wrong.

issue.body:
This adds reproducible memory error and test-data
error injection, to the fuzzy-test framework.

This feature can be enabled with ./config -DERROR_INJECT and additionally to enable call stacks -DERROR_CALLSTACK

If enable-asan is used, the callstack is printed by the sanitizer, otherwise please set a breakpoint
at the function "break_here", which is executed each time a memory allocation error is injected.

If called with the environment variable ERROR_INJECT defined to the empty string the initialization value is printed, and can be used to reproduce the failure later, by passing the value to the ERROR_INJECT variable.

There is a search script that can be used to look
for errors, and print the command to reproduce the bug:

./testrun.sh

This runs in endless mode until an error is found.

pull_request.title: Fix error handling in OBJ_add_object
pull_request.body:
This fixes the possible memory leak in OBJ_add_object when a pre-existing object is replaced by a new one, with identical NID, OID, and/or short/long name.
We do not try to delete any orphans, but only mark them as type == -1, because the previously returned pointers from OBJ_nid2obj/OBJ_nid2sn/OBJ_nid2ln
may be cached by applications and can thus not
be cleaned up before the application terminates.

-->

issue.body:
OpenSSL's encoding of SM2 keys used the SM2 OID for the algorithm OID
where an AlgorithmIdentifier is encoded (for encoding into the structures
PrivateKeyInfo and SubjectPublicKeyInfo).

Such keys should be encoded as ECC keys.

Fixes #22184

comment.body:
> > Compared to actual standards?
> 
> I don't think there is a standard for this AFAIK - which is part of the problem (or at least there wasn't - maybe there is now somewhere).

Well, yes and no.  SM2 is piggy backed on ECC, and the key itself is really an ECC key, just with a very specific curve, and with a slightly different algorithm to sign and verify.

So I'm leaning on this being a confusion, at least in terms of AlgorithmIndentifier.  "there is no standard" could very well be "there is an ECC encoding standard, use that".

@romen, could I ask for a comment from you?

pull_request.title: Create a rudimentary symbol scanning script
pull_request.body:
We would like to be able to log and audit the symbols we use in openssl so that we might catch when a new platform symbols is referecned

Add such a script (just on unix platforms for now) that gathers the used symbols not belonging to libcrypto or libssl, and compare it to a prior known set of used symbols.  Error out if a new symbol is found

Add this script to the static analysis workflow in CI to capture newly introduced platform symbols

Fixes #22330

pull_request.title: apps: req/x509 add explicit start and end date
pull_request.body:
This feature adds options to explicitly set the start and end dates in X509v3 certificate creation with the `req` and `x509` apps.
I stumbled upon this several times now, and I think this adds some convenience to the apps.

For the `req` app, I borrowed the naming from the `ca` app, hence the parameters are called `-startdate` and `-enddate`. I also added the same handling for `default_startdate` and `default_enddate` to the respective configuration file section.
The `-enddate` option conflicts with the `-days` option, hence only one of both can be used. If a start date is given, but no end date, the `-days` option is processed instead. Currently, this results in an offset of days from the current date, not from the start date.

For the `x509` app, I had to select different names, as `-startdate` and `-enddate` are already in use to print the `notBefore` and `notAfter` fields of a certificate. Therefore, I called the options `-notbefore` and `-notafter`. The handling in respect to the `-days` option is similar to the `req` app, but no configuration file parameters exist.

Changes:
- removed new configuration options from `req` app.
- renamed options `-startdate` and `-enddate` to `-notbefore` and `-notafter` in `req` app.
- Ensure notafter >= notbefore in both apps `req` and `x509`.
- Improved docs.

For the `req` app, I borrowed the naming from the `ca` app, hence the parameters are called `-startdate` and `-enddate`. I also added the same handling for `default_startdate` and `default_enddate` to the respective configuration file section.
The `-enddate` option conflicts with the `-days` option, hence only one of both can be used. If a start date is given, but no end date, the `-days` option is processed instead. Currently, this results in an offset of days from the current date, not from the start date.

For the `x509` app, I had to select different names, as `-startdate` and `-enddate` are already in use to print the `notBefore` and `notAfter` fields of a certificate. Therefore, I called the options `-notbefore` and `-notafter`. The handling in respect to the `-days` option is similar to the `req` app, but no configuration file parameters exist.

- removed new configuration options from `req` app.
- renamed options `-startdate` and `-enddate` to `-notbefore` and `-notafter` in `req` app.
- Ensure notafter >= notbefore in both apps `req` and `x509`.

issue.title: Fix the encoding of SM2 keys

labels.name: branch: master
labels.description: Merge to master branch

labels.name: hold: need otc decision
labels.description: The OTC needs to make a decision

labels.name: branch: 3.0
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.0 branch

labels.name: branch: 3.1
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.1

labels.name: branch: 3.2
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.2

issue.body:
OpenSSL's encoding of SM2 keys used the SM2 OID for the algorithm OID
where an AlgorithmIdentifier is encoded (for encoding into the structures
PrivateKeyInfo and SubjectPublicKeyInfo).

Such keys should be encoded as ECC keys.

Fixes #22184

comment.body:
A question is also, how does 1.1.1 encode SM2 keys?

So the question is, have we caused a regression of some sort?  Compared to our own older versions?  Compared to the rest of the world (#22184 at least indicates that we don't agree with what others expect)?  Compared to actual standards?

pull_request.title: Add Reproducible Error Injection (rebased)
pull_request.body:
This adds reproducible memory error and test-data
error injection, to the fuzzy-test framework.

This feature can be enabled with ./config -DERROR_INJECT and additionally to enable call stacks -DERROR_CALLSTACK

If enable-asan is used, the callstack is printed by the sanitizer, otherwise please set a breakpoint
at the function "break_here", which is executed each time a memory allocation error is injected.

If called with the environment variable ERROR_INJECT defined to the empty string the initialization value is printed, and can be used to reproduce the failure later, by passing the value to the ERROR_INJECT variable.

There is a search script that can be used to look
for errors, and print the command to reproduce the bug:

./testrun.sh

This runs in endless mode until an error is found.

pull_request.title: Add Reproducible Error Injection (rebased)
pull_request.body:
This adds reproducible memory error and test-data
error injection, to the fuzzy-test framework.

This feature can be enabled with ./config -DERROR_INJECT and additionally to enable call stacks -DERROR_CALLSTACK

If enable-asan is used, the callstack is printed by the sanitizer, otherwise please set a breakpoint
at the function "break_here", which is executed each time a memory allocation error is injected.

If called with the environment variable ERROR_INJECT defined to the empty string the initialization value is printed, and can be used to reproduce the failure later, by passing the value to the ERROR_INJECT variable.

There is a search script that can be used to look
for errors, and print the command to reproduce the bug:

./testrun.sh

This runs in endless mode until an error is found.

issue.body:
This adds reproducible memory error and test-data
error injection, to the fuzzy-test framework.

This feature can be enabled with ./config -DERROR_INJECT and additionally to enable call stacks -DERROR_CALLSTACK

If enable-asan is used, the callstack is printed by the sanitizer, otherwise please set a breakpoint
at the function "break_here", which is executed each time a memory allocation error is injected.

If called with the environment variable ERROR_INJECT defined to the empty string the initialization value is printed, and can be used to reproduce the failure later, by passing the value to the ERROR_INJECT variable.

There is a search script that can be used to look
for errors, and print the command to reproduce the bug:

./testrun.sh

This runs in endless mode until an error is found.

issue.title: Fix the encoding of SM2 keys

labels.name: branch: master
labels.description: Merge to master branch

labels.name: hold: need otc decision
labels.description: The OTC needs to make a decision

labels.name: branch: 3.0
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.0 branch

labels.name: branch: 3.1
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.1

labels.name: branch: 3.2
labels.description: Merge to openssl-3.2

issue.body:
OpenSSL's encoding of SM2 keys used the SM2 OID for the algorithm OID
where an AlgorithmIdentifier is encoded (for encoding into the structures
PrivateKeyInfo and SubjectPublicKeyInfo).

Such keys should be encoded as ECC keys.

Fixes #22184

comment.body:
I was under the impression that the SM2 OID is the preferred way to do this now - but maybe we're the only tool actually using it. It might be we need some option for this for interoperability purposes.

**OTC Question: Which OID should we be using for the SM2 AlgorithmIdentifier?**
